title: 107_hr110
content: The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows small farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit for charitable conservation contributions of land. The "Private Land Conservation Tax Act" allows eligible farmers and ranchers to receive a tax credit equal to 10 percent of the amount that would be allowed as a deduction for a qualified conservation contribution. The maximum credit for any taxable year is $360,000, minus the aggregate amount allowed in the previous 15 years. The tax credit under subsection (a) is limited to $360,000 per year, minus the total credits claimed in the previous 15 years. Joint returns split the credit equally between spouses. All members of the same controlled group of corporations are treated as one taxpayer. The tax credit under subsection (a) is limited to $360,000 per year, minus the total credits claimed in the previous 15 years. All members of the same controlled group of corporations are treated as one taxpayer. The credit allowed for any taxable year shall not exceed the regular tax reduced by the sum of credits allowable under subpart A and the preceding sections, over the tentative minimum tax. An eligible farmer or rancher is defined as a taxpayer whose gross income from farming is 60 percent or more of their total gross income. The tax credit for income from farming is limited to $360,000 per year, with special rules for C corporations. The corporation's gross income from farming must be 60% or more of its total income, its stock cannot be publicly traded, and its farming assets' value must not exceed $20,000,000. Taxpayers must elect to apply this section for the taxable year, and the election is irrevocable. The taxpayer must elect to apply the tax credit for income from farming for the taxable year, and this election is irrevocable. No deduction is allowed under section 170 for a qualified conservation contribution if the taxpayer chooses to take the credit for such contribution. Any excess credit for a taxable year can be carried forward to the succeeding year. The taxpayer must elect to apply the tax credit for income from farming for the taxable year, and this election is irrevocable. Any excess credit for a taxable year can be carried forward to the succeeding year. A conforming amendment is made to the table of sections for subpart B of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Code. Sec. 30B: Private land conservation. The amendments apply to donations of qualified conservation contributions made after the enactment date. Sec. 3: Increase in charitable contribution limit for farmers and ranchers in corporate form. The Internal Revenue Code is amended to treat qualified farmers and ranchers as individuals for conservation contributions. The amendments apply to taxable years ending after the enactment date. The amendment expands the estate tax exclusion for land under a qualified conservation easement. It applies to estates of decedents dying after the enactment date.
